oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Bard, 1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: W. Hoffert Photograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shown here at age 74, John Bard was a member of a distinguished family of doctors and educators. His grandfather and great-grandfather, Drs. Samuel and John Bard respectively, were preeminent physicians who practiced both in New York City and from their family estate at Hyde Park, NY. His father, William Bard was a lawyer who founded and administered the Life and Trust Company, the first life insurance company in NYS. Together with his wife, Margaret Johnston Bard, a devout woman and a committed philanthropist, John Bard worked tirelessly to create local schools and churches for their community, both at their estate in Annandale, and in the nearby village of Tivoli (then Myersville). In the 1850s, they built Bard Hall at Annandale which was used as a chapel and a parish school for local children. They subsequently built the Church of the Holy Innocents in 1857, and rebuilt this a year later when the original was destroyed by fire. They also worked with James Starr Clark of Tivoli to build Trinity Church and School, which included a parish school in the basement , and then Trinity Academy, a school for young boys. In 1860, along with other like-minded men, they founded St. Stephens College, a training school for young men who intended to pursue careers as Episcopal Ministers. With the death of their only son Willie in 1868, the Bards, along with their three daughters removed to Europe, partially to escape the weight of their grief. Margaret died in 1875, but John Bard maintained an interest in the institutions he had helped found until his deathin 1899. He is buried in the Bard cemetery. In 1934, the trustees of St.Stephens College renamed the college Bard in honor of its founders who had transformed the cultural climate of the area.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Margaret Johnston Bard
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peirce, D.S.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Margaret Johnston Bard poses for a formal portrait, wearing a long velvet dress. Though few of her personal papers remain, Margaret Bard was known for her intelligence and religious devotion. Her family fortune brought wealth to John Bard through their marriage in 1849, and her dedication to religious and social causes was clearly a spur to the legacy of philanthropic activity for which the Bard name is remembered. She made a personal appeal to James Starr Clark to build Trinity Church and School in neighboring Tivoli (then Myersville)--a cause to which he subsequently devoted almost three decades of his life. Her name is also included among the first Board of Trustees for St. Stephen's College. This was an unusual role for a woman in 1860, and it stands as a testament to her own gifts, as well as to the strength of her partnership with John Bard. She is memorialized by a headstone in the Bard cemetery, and by St. Margaret's Well, which stands next to the Chapel of Holy Innocents, erected a year after her death in 1875.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: China Doll Head
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This doll head was found ca. 1975 behind the site of the former Trinity School and Home, later called the Watts de Peyster Home for Girls. During the early decades of the 20th century it was customary for villagers to dump trash along the banks of the local creek. When the school was torn down in 1938, the contents of the building were apparently dumped in this way. In the 1970's, Tivoli children would dig for "treasure" from an earlier era; wire framed eyeglasses, brown earthenware jugs, and crumbling leather lace up shoes were prized finds. Though most such treasures from this site were doll fragments, this head was found whole, protected in part by a thick root growing through its center. The unmatched eyes were also found at this site.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rev. James Starr Clark
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographed here as a distinguished older man, James Starr Clark was a pivotal figure in the 19th century history of Tivoli. Arriving at Annandale in the early 1850's as a tutor to the Bard children, he lived with the family for two years, during which time he developed a close, trusting relationship with the family. Hard working himself, and on good terms with working people, Clark was the ideal man to implement many of the Bards' philanthropic causes in the immediate and surrounding areas. Appointed 'Missionary of Annandale' in 1854, Clark was instrumental in starting the first parish school at Annandale. Margaret Bard reportedly promised funds and asked him to use his talents to start a school in nearby Tivoli (then Madalin, also called Myersville), and he agreed. Chief among his many contributions to the village of Tivoli were the construction of Trinity Church and School, and Trinity Academy, a boarding school for young boys which operated under his direction for 26 years. Clark was a major force behind the incorporation and merger of Tivoli and Madalin in 1872, and he served as the first President of the Village of Tivoli. A year later he was re-elected to this office, where he oversaw many improvements to the village's infrastructure, and provided a needed social stability as the village grew and changed. Financial difficulties forced him to sell Trinity Church and School, along with Trinity Academy in 1893, and he accepted another position to head Mt. Mintern, a home and school for neglected children near Elmsford, NY. He died in 1914 at the age of 92.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: De Peyster Home, Tivoli, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kingston Souvenir Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Originally built under the direction of James Starr Clark with funds provided by John and Margaret Bard, this school had many names throughout its history. It began as Trinity School and Home, sometimes called Trinity Academy. When Clark expanded the school, a military element was added, and the school became known as the Trinity Military Institute, or T.M.I. References are also made to Clark's Military Academy. At its height in 1881 the school served 60 boys, but an economic downturn in the early 1890's brought the total number of students down to 4. Clark sold the school to General John Watts de Peyster, who donated the school to a Methodist Home for Girls, and the name was changed one last time to the Watts De Peyster Industrial Home and School. The school was torn down in 1938.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Bard
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: J. Curney & Son
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Posing here as a young man, John Bard was born in 1819 to a distinguished family of doctors and educators. His grandfather and great-grandfather, Drs. Samuel and John Bard respectively, were preeminent physicians who practiced both in New York City and from their family estate at Hyde Park, NY. His father, William Bard was a lawyer who founded and administered the "Life and Trust Company," the first life insurance company in NYS. Together with his wife, Margaret Johnston Bard, a devout woman and a committed philanthropist, John Bard worked tirelessly to create local schools and churches for their community, both at their estate in Annandale, and in the nearby village of Tivoli (then Myersville). In the 1850's, they built Bard Hall at Annandale which was used as a chapel and a parish school for local children. They subsequently built the Church of the Holy Innocents in 1857, and rebuilt this a year later when the original was destroyed by fire. They also worked with James Starr Clark of Tivoli to build Trinity Church and School, which included a parish school in the basement , and then Trinity Academy, a school for young boys. In 1860, along with other like-minded men, they founded St. Stephens College, a training school for young men who intended to pursue careers as Episcopal Ministers. With the death of their only son Willie in 1868, the Bards, along with their three daughters removed to Europe, partially to escape the weight of their grief. Margaret died in 1875, but John Bard maintained an interest in the institutions he had helped found until his deathin 1899. He is buried in the Bard cemetery. In 1934, the trustees of St.Stephens College renamed the college Bard in honor of its founders who had transformed the cultural climate of the area.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Starr Clark
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured here as a young man, James Starr Clark came to Annandale in the 1850's as a tutor to the Bard children. He lived with the family for two years, during which time he developed a close, trusting relationship with the family. Hard working himself, and on good terms with working people, Clark was the ideal man to implement many of the Bards' philanthropic causes in the immediate and surrounding areas. Appointed 'Missionary of Annandale' in 1854, Clark was instrumental in starting the first parish school at Annandale. Margaret Bard reportedly promised funds and asked him to use his talents to start a school in nearby Tivoli (then Madalin, also called Myersville), and he agreed. Chief among his many contributions to the village of Tivoli were the construction of Trinity Church and School, and Trinity School, a boarding school for young boys which operated under his direction for 26 years. Clark was a major force behind the incorporation and merger of Tivoli and Madalin in 1872 and he served as the first President of the Village of Tivoli. A year later he was re-elected to this office, where he oversaw many improvements to the village's infrastructure, and provided a needed social stability as the village grew and changed. Financial difficulties forced him to sell Trinity Church and School, along with Trinity Academy in 1893, and he accepted another position to head Mt. Mintern, a home and school for neglected children near Elmsford, NY. He died in 1914 at the age of 92.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hartzell Album, Page 11
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hartzell, Paul
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This page displaying three photographs is titled: "Returning with Algebra, Sat. a.m. June 12, 1915" The significance of the mock funeral depicted is described in a 1930 issue of the student newspaper, the Lyre Tree: "There is a tradition of long standing at St. Stephen's that within 30 days after the close of the first semester the Freshman class shall, with all the ritual and solemnity due the occasion, secretly inter an algebra, autographed by each member of the class and with it a certain quantity of wine. To be legal, every Freshman must be at the grave during the burial. At the end of the four years, the algebra is exhumed and burned on a funeral pyre, during the Class Day exercises. Toasts are drunk to the college, and to the outgoing and incoming Senior class."
